headline: Hush Puppies
description: These hush puppies are made from a simple batter with a hint of celery and garlic. They are quick and easy and ready in less than 30 minutes.
name: Hush Puppies
recipeIngredient: 1 quart vegetable oil for frying, or as needed
1 pinch Cajun seasoning, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a deep-fryer or large saucepan to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Mix flour, cornmeal, onion, milk, egg, celery, garlic, and Cajun seasoning in a bowl.

Drop ping pong ball-sized balls of batter, about 5 at a time, into the hot oil. Fry until golden brown, about 5 minutes. Remove hush puppies with a slotted spoon and drain on a paper towel-lined plate. Repeat with remaining batter.

review.reviewBody: Other than having to add more self rising cornbread mix to make the "ping pong balls" a little stiffer so they held up to the cooking, I followed the recipe. The texture was so light & delicious!! I'll be making these again!...... Barb in Arkansas

Great recipe! I converted it to GF using 1/2 cup of Cup4Cup GF flour and 1/2 cup PAN sweet cornmeal mix (I found it in the Hispanic section of a Food Depot). That's all I needed to change. I've already made them twice.
Very good recipe! I changed the seasoning to blackening seasoning and it was delicious!
Outstanding! I like a little more Cajun but spot on! Reminds me of Flips barbecue in North Carolina.
Not sure what I did wrong but batter was way too thin. Just fried into pieces and tasted like grease. Big NO for me.
I loved this recipe. The flavor profile was excellent.
Sooooo good. I didn’t have corn flour but did have jiffy cornbread mix. Turned out perfectly

I found this recipe when my husband and I were having a shrimp for dinner. It was absolutely delicious ?? . I will most certainly be using the hush puppy recipe many times ! Thanks for such a delightful side dish when we have seafood ??
Easy and really good
These didn't hold together at all! Don't know why. Won't be trying this one again.

I made this today- first time ever for making hush puppies! I have never been a fan of hush puppies- but hubby is. They were the best ones I have ever tried! With reading other reviews- I did omit celery and garlic- but did add garlic salt and a little white sugar- that were awesome!! Thanks for sharing!!
awesome to eat any time, even as a snack.

Loved the consistency and flavor, but were a little bland. I added a fresh jalapeño from the garden. Chopped it in the chopper with the onion. Next time will add more jalapeño, Cajun seasoning and salt. It is a keeper.

I made as directed but took other's advice and added more spice and also added sugar. I tasted the batter until it tasted right and then cooked it. OH!! I almost forgot! I added about 1/2 tsp of baking powder. I fried them
In peanut oil at about 375 and they puffed up beautifully and were DELISH!!
Very little flavor. Had to add a lot of seasoning to make them edible
These were gummy and just tasteless. But easy to make.
This simple & easy I added some onion soup mix instead of Cajun seasoning they are fantastic
No onion, celery, or Cajun seasoning. Hit with kids.
It would be helpful to know how many this recipe makes.

This southerner approves! I use seasoning salt and garlic powder instead of fresh garlic. I also add 2Tbs of melted butter to the wet ingredients (plus a little extra corn meal). Rest of recipe is spot-on! Thanks!

Followed the recipe exactly - turned out fine, but tasted like fried stuffing. Not quite what I was looking for - plan to try a different recipe again.
Was quick, though, just like I was looking for!
love this recipe. Be sure to add more flour than corn meal, also a little salt.

I read several of the reviews where they said they were runny, or too wet. So were mine. I couldn't get them to clump up in balls. That's not to say these weren't bad. I followed the recipe exactly except I added a little sugar. Very good. I will also try these again to see if I can master the batter by getting them to clump up better

The batter was quite gooey, which meant that the hush puppies came out in some fanciful, Dr. Seuss-like shapes. That said, they tasted GREAT! Next time I'll add a little bit of flour to stiffen up the dough, make it easier to mold into balls, and hopefully make them more uniform in shape. I'll make this again.
These were so good! Added jalapenos and old bay and more Cajun seasoning. Everyone loved them!

I just got done making these...we hoped they would turn out better. The batter was VERY runny and that made it hard to get the shape right so I suggest adding more flour. Also, they were really bland so we will add sugar to the batter next time if we make them again. Adding butter and sugar on top really helped and made them savory and sweet. Good luck making these! They turned out pretty good with a few adjustments. (we left out the celery)
Very good recipe. I added a little Tony Cacheres seasoning to the mix to give them some spice and they were excellent!
It needed more flavor. I expected to be able to mix them into balls but they just kinda flattened out when frying. Will not try this one again.

Very good recipe, turned out great. I like sweet hush puppies so I added a little sugar. To the reviewer that thought the batter was too runny, add small equal parts of flour and corn meal until you get the right thickness.
Quick and easy. 5+ stars in my kitchen
don't know what i did wrong with these but the batter was extremely runny so it made it hard to fry....other than that it tasted good :)
great recipe. The recipe is more family size than party size, which makes good for the weekday dinner. The hushpuppies are moist and very tasty. Definetly give this recipe a try.
A little extra cajun seasoning and these are great!
